Launch File
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul
tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 Multiple Processes for One Application
Recall that you may have to open multiple console and
execute multiple commands just to run one robot application
Example: Project 2
Terminal 1: ROS Master
roscore

Terminal 2: Kobuki Node
roslaunch kobuki_node minimal.launch

Terminal 3: gscam Node
roslaunch gscam v4l.launch

Terminal 4: cmvision Node
roslaunch mypackage cmvision.launch

Terminal 5: Constant command
rosrun mypackage constant_command.py

Terminal 6: Control node for project 2
rosrun mypackage project2.py
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 Multiple Processes for One Application

ROS allows you to execute one single command which results
in executing multiple processes
You need a launch file
In ROS, a launch file is a text file with XML style (tags) with
the extension .launch
Traditionally located in the launch directory under your
package
/home/student/cs1567/src/mypackage/launch

But it can be located anywhere under your package
(mypackage) directory

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 The <launch> Tag

All content of the launch file must be surrounded by the
<launch> tag:
<launch>
<!-- This is a comment -->

</launch>

A comment must be surrounded by <!-- and --> as shown
above

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 The <include> Tag

To let the launch file execute another launch file, use the
<include> tag
<launch>
:
<!-- roslaunch kobuki_node minimal.launch -->
<include file="$(find kobuki_node)/launch/minimal.launch"/>
:
</launch>

The $(find kobuki node) will result in the path to the
location of the kobuki node package
In case of the kobuki node package, the launch file is located
under the launch directory

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 The <include> Tag
For other packages, simply navigate to the package’s directory
using roscd and look for it
For example, gscam:
student@robot:/home/student$ roscd gscam
student@robot:/opt/ros/kinetic/share/gscam$ ls
cmake
gscam_nodeletlaunch
nodelet_plugins.xml
examples nodelet_pipeline.launch package.xml

v4l.launch

Note that launch files of gscam package are not in the
launch directory
Thus, for the gscam node:
<launch>
:
<!-- roslaunch gscam v4l.launch -->
<include file="$(find gscam)/v4l.launch"/>
:
</launch>

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 The <node> Tag
To let the launch file execute a node, use the <node> tag
<launch>
:
<!-- rosrun mypackage constant_command.py -->
<node name="constant_command" pkg="mypackage"
type="constant_command.py"/>
:
</launch>

The name indicates the name of the node
In most case, it should be the same as the in
rospy.init node()
Different name will overwrite the node name when it is
initialized

The pkg indicates the name of the package
The type indicates the name of the executable file

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 The <node> Tag
Let’s put them all together for project 2 (p2.launch)
<launch>
<!-- roslaunch kobuki_node minimal.launch -->
<include file="$(find kobuki_node)/launch/minimal.launch"/>
<!-- roslaunch gscam v4l.launch -->
<include file="$(find gscam)/v4l.launch"/>
<!-- roslaunch mypackage cmvision.launch -->
<include file="$(find mypackage)/cmvision.launch"/>
<!-- rosrun mypackage constant_command.py -->
<node name="constant_command" pkg="mypackage" type="constant_command.py"/>
<!-- rosrun mypackage project2.py -->
<node name="project2" pkg="mypackage" type="project2.py" output="screen" cwd="node"/>
</launch>

Notes:
If your node needs to show output on the console screen, you
need to add output="screen" as shown above
The cwd="node" specifies the working directory to be the
location of the executable file
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu

Launch File

 The launch File

To use the previous launch file:
roslaunch mypackage p2.launch

You do not need to run the roscore command
If the roscore is not currently running, the launch file will
also execute the roscore command

You only need one console screen
If all your nodes support Ctrl-C, by pressing Ctrl-C, it will
kill all program executed by the launch file

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul tkosiyat@cs.pitt.edu
